close_symbols: enum: all MHD_CONNECTION_* state constants (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_HEADERS_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED, MHD_CONNECTION_CONTINUE_SENDING, MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_FOOTERS_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_FOOTERS_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REQ_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_START_REPLY, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_SENDING, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_SENT, MHD_CONNECTION_NORMAL_BODY_READY, MHD_CONNECTION_NORMAL_BODY_UNREADY, MHD_CONNECTION_CHUNKED_BODY_READY, MHD_CONNECTION_CHUNKED_BODY_UNREADY, MHD_CONNECTION_CHUNKED_BODY_SENT, MHD_CONNECTION_FOOTERS_SENDING, MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REPLY_SENT, MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED, MHD_CONNECTION_UPGRADE)

struct: MHD_Connection (complete layout used by the function: suspended, state, tls_state, continue_message_write_offset, write_buffer_send_offset, write_buffer_append_offset, write_buffer[], rq.url, daemon, keepalive, rp substructure, etc.)
struct: MHD_Response (fields used: data_size, data_start, crc, total_size, data, data_iov, mutex)
struct/substruct: connection->rp (response-properties and runtime fields: response pointer, props.send_reply_body, props.chunked, rsp_write_position, resp_sender, resp_iov)
function: MHD_send_data_ (semantics: return values and side effects)
function: MHD_send_hdr_and_body_ (semantics: return values and side effects)
explanation:
To decide whether any case bodies in MHD_connection_handle_write are genuinely unreachable (MISRA: no unreachable code) the analyzer needs the following definitions/semantics:

- All MHD_CONNECTION_* state constants: The switch is on connection->state; to determine whether particular case labels can ever occur you must know the full enum/defines and their values.

- struct MHD_Connection layout: The function reads many fields (suspended, state, tls_state, write offsets, write buffer, rq.url, daemon, keepalive, rp). Whether early returns or particular switch cases are reachable depends on these fields and their meanings.

- struct MHD_Response and connection->rp layout: The body-selection logic (data_size, data_start, crc, total_size, data_iov, mutex, props, rsp_write_position, resp_sender, resp_iov) controls which branches are taken (headers vs body, chunked vs normal). Knowing these fields and their invariants is necessary to decide if branches/case labels are possible.

- MHD_ERR_AGAIN_, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_, MHD_CONN_MUST_UPGRADE, HTTP_100_CONTINUE, SIZE_MAX, and mhd_assert: These macros/constants affect control flow and guards in the function (error checks, loop/progress conditions and assertions). In particular MHD_ERR_AGAIN_ is tested to decide whether the function returns (making later code unreachable at that call-site); mhd_assert(0) marks places asserted-to-be-impossible—whether they are truly impossible depends on the surrounding semantics.

- CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR and the underlying connection_close_error / MHD_connection_close_: Several branches call these to close the connection and return. To decide reachability of subsequent code you must know whether these calls always return, abort, or change state in a way relevant to later code.

- check_write_done and try_ready_normal_body: These two functions are invoked from within the case arms and are the primary helpers that change connection->state or the rp.rsp_write_position. Determining whether some case arms (especially those containing mhd_assert(0)) are reachable requires their precise behavior/side-effects (which states they set or whether they can transition to states that later cause the switch to select other cases).

- MHD_send_data_, MHD_send_hdr_and_body_, MHD_send_sendfile_, MHD_send_iovec_: These I/O helpers return values that control branching (ret < 0, MHD_ERR_AGAIN_, amount sent) and may have side-effects on connection state/offsets; their return semantics are needed to determine which subsequent statements can execute.

- MHD_update_last_activity_ and MHD_run_tls_handshake_: The TLS handshake call may return early and change control flow; update_last_activity_ is invoked in many places and may have side-effects (and its implementation uses __builtin_unreachable in the call-graph), so its semantics matter for reachability.

- Compile-time flags (HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, _MHD_HAVE_SENDFILE, HAVE_MESSAGES): Presence/absence of these conditionally includes/excludes code paths (e.g. HTTPS handshake, UPGRADE case, sendfile branch). MISRA analysis must consider the actual build configuration; a branch that is compiled out is not part of the binary and therefore not subject to the unreachable-code rule.

Collectively these symbols provide the definitions and side‑effect semantics needed to determine whether the labelled switch cases and other guarded blocks are actually executable in any feasible program build/execution. Without them you cannot conclude whether mhd_assert(0) sites or other branches are truly unreachable (MISRA violation) or intentionally defensive but reachable.
